questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for bacterial vaginosis?
questions.solution:
Caucasian race is not a risk factor for bacterial vaginosis. 

The risk factors for bacterial vaginosis are:

  1. Oral sex
  2. Vaginal douching
  3. African race
  4. Cigarette smoking
  5. Sex during menses
  6. Intrauterine device
  7. Early age of sexual intercourse
  8. New or multiple sexual partners
  9. Sexual activity with other women

Note: Bacterial vaginosis is not an infection. It most commonly affects young women. Although it is not a sexually transmitted disease, the chances of developing bacterial vaginosis seem to increase with the number of sexual partners that a woman has had.

questions.text: A young woman was suspected to have bacterial vaginosis. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: Gardnerella vaginalis is a causative agent
Amsel’s criteria is used for diagnosis
Oral metronidazole is given for treatment

questions.solution:
Vaginal itching is not seen in bacterial vaginosis. It is a symptom of Trichomonas vaginitis.

About half of the women having bacterial vaginosis are asymptomatic. Symptomatic women mostly present with a profuse, fishy vaginal discharge. It does not cause pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia.

Option A: Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to the absence of lactobacilli. This causes an increase in the growth of other anaerobic bacteria namely Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus, and Myco­plasma hominis.

Option B: Amsel's criteria is used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis. 3 out of 4 criteria are needed to make a positive diagnosis.

Option D: Oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or oral clindamycin 300 mg twice daily for 7 days is given for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. Treatment remains the same in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 30-year old woman presents to your OPD with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge for the past 2 weeks. On examination, the discharge is adherent to the vaginal mucosa and has a fishy odour. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis (BV) caused by Gardnerella. 

Patients with BV have profuse and yellowish vaginal discharge with a fishy odour. It is adherent to the vaginal mucosa. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are absent. On microscopy, clue cells are visible.

Option A: In trichomonas vaginitis, the vaginal discharge is frothy, greenish-yellow and has an offensive smell. Dysuria, dyspareunia, and vaginal itching are generally present. 

Option B: In candidal vaginitis, the discharge is thick and curdy white.

Option D: In chlamydial infection, the vaginal discharge is generally scanty.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: In a patient with bacterial vaginosis, which of the following microscopic features would not be seen?
questions.solution:
An abundance of polymorphs is not a microscopic finding of bacterial vaginosis because it is not an inflammatory condition. It occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora.

A swab of the discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopic evaluation is done using a gram stained smear. In bacterial vaginosis, this would reveal a clean background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organ­isms, and a reduced number of Lactobacilli would also be seen. 

Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a smear prepared from the vaginal discharge of a patient. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of clue cells on microscopy is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis.

A swab of the vaginal discharge is taken from the vaginal wall and a smear is prepared. The microscopic evaluation of the smear is done on a gram stained smear. It would reveal a clean background with an abundance of gram variable coccobacilli adhering to the epithelial cells. These are called clue cells. A few inflammatory cells, other pathogenic organ­isms, and a reduced number of Lactobacilli would also be seen. 

Shown below is the Gram-stained smear of vaginal discharge of a patient diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. It reveals vaginal epithelial cells that have a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are called clue cells.

questions.text: A woman comes to the clinic with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. On examination, the discharge was profuse and had a fishy odour. Which of the following is the best criteria to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis which is confirmed by using Amsel’s criteria. 

3 out of 4 of the following criteria are needed, to make a positive diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis:

  1. A homogeneous, thin, greyish-white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls.
  2. A vaginal pH > 4.5.
  3. A positive whiff test - an amine like fishy odour is produced when a drop of 10% KOH is added to the sample of vaginal discharge.
  4. The presence of >20% clue cells on saline wet mount. These are vaginal epithelial cells studded with adherent coccobacilli at the edge of the cell.

Option A: Boer-Miesel's criteria is used for the prognostic evaluation of pelvic inflammatory disease.

Option B: Light's criteria is used for determining the nature of the pleural fluid i.e., transudate or exudate, in the diagnosis of pleural effusion.

Option D: Nugent's criteria can also be used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis. However, it is not the best confirmatory method.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

Candidal vaginitis

Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: In a patient with suspected bacterial vaginosis, Nugent's criteria is used to quantify the following bacteria except....
questions.solution:
Nugent's criteria is used to evaluate three types of bacteria in a case of suspected bacterial vaginosis: Mobiluncus, Lactobacillus, and Gardnerella/Bacteroides. Bacteria are graded through gram stain of vaginal samples. 

They are each graded on a scale of 1+ to 4+ where:

  • 1+ is < 1 cell per field
  • 2+ is 1-5 cells per field
  • 3+ is 6-30 cells per field
  • 4+ is >30 cells per field

Lactobacillus and Bacteroides/Gardnerella are given scores between 0-4, but Mobiluncus is graded only from 0-2. The total scores are then calculated and interpreted as follows:

  • 0-3 - Normal
  • 4-6 - Intermediate bacterial count
  • 7-10 - Bacterial vaginosis

questions.text: A gynaecology resident noted a frothy, greenish, offensive-smelling vaginal discharge in a young lady. Whiff test was positive. Which organism is most likely implicated?
questions.solution:
Trichomonas vaginalis is the likely organism implicated in this patient, causing trichomonas vaginitis.

The whiff test can be positive in both Trichomonas and Gardnerella infections. However, greenish frothy discharge is seen in trichomonas vaginitis.

questions.text: A patient came to the gynaecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, Trichomonas vaginalis is the likely causative agent.

Vaginal itching and foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge are seen in trichomonas vaginitis.

The given image shows colpitis macularis or strawberry cervix, which is a characteristic finding of trichomoniasis. This is due to microscopic, punctate haemorrhages of the cervix.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms can be detected on a hanging drop preparation?
questions.solution:
Trichomonas vaginalis can be detected on a hanging drop preparation. Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan with four anterior flagellae, and a fifth posterior flagellum responsible for motility.

The image given below shows trophozoites of Trichomonas vaginalis with flagella.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman came with complaints of greenish vaginal discharge. On saline microscopy, motile flagellated organisms were seen. What is the best treatment option for her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trichomonas vaginitis and the best treatment option for her is oral metronidazole 2 g stat.

The treatment regimen for trichomonas vaginitis is:

  • An oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or
  • A single oral dose of metronidazole 2 g  

The male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in case of recurrent infection. Treatment in pregnancy remains the same.

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her 7th week of gestation was diagnosed with trichomoniasis. Which of the following can be used to treat her condition?
questions.solution:
Trichomonas vaginitis is treated with oral metronidazole in pregnant women.

According to the current guidelines, metronidazole is now considered safe for treating trichomonas vaginitis in pregnancy as it has no teratogenic effect.

The treatment regimen for trichomonas vaginitis in pregnant women include:

  1. An oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or a single oral dose of metronidazole 2 g  
  2. Usage of trichofuran suppositories
  3. Vinegar douche to lower the vaginal pH
  4. Betadine gel

The male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole in case of recurrent infection.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic woman presents to your OPD with complaints of curdy white vaginal discharge and intense itching. What is the likely causative agent for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of moniliasis and Candida albicans is the likely causative agent.

The risk factors for moniliasis are:

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Immunosuppression
  • HIV
  • Pregnancy
  • Steroid therapy
  • Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Poor personal hygiene.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: In an obese lady with complaints of vaginal discharge, a vaginal pH of 4.2 was detected. Which organism is implicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely causative agent in the given clinical scenario is Candida which is known to flourish in an acidic environment. The pH of the vaginal discharge in candidal vaginitis is in the range of 4-4.5.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing a candidal infection?
questions.solution:
Hypertension does not increase the risk of developing a candidal infection.

The risk factors for developing candidal vaginitis (moniliasis) are: 

  • Diabe­tes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Immunosuppression
  • HIV
  • Pregnancy
  • Steroid therapy
  • Following long-term broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Poor personal hygiene.

questions.text: A 32-year old woman presents to you with complaints of vaginal discharge and itching. On examination, you note a curdy white discharge and an inflamed vagina. What is the best treatment for her?
questions.solution: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of candidal vaginitis. A single dose of fluconazole 150 mg is the best treatment for treating candidal vaginitis. Intravaginal antifungal (imidazole/miconazole/clotrimazole) vaginal pessaries or creams can also be used for 3–6 days.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary site for gonococcal infection?
questions.solution:
Ectocervix and vagina are lined by squamous epithelium which is resistant to gonococcal infection.

The principal sites of invasion for gonococcal infection are the columnar and transitional epithelium. Hence, gonococcus usually affects the following structures:

  • Endocervix
  • Urethra
  • Skene’s glands
  • Bartholin's glands.

questions.text: Which of the following presentations is unlikely to be seen in a patient with gonorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Haematuria is unlikely to be seen in a patient with gonorrhoea.

Gynaecological presentation of gonorrhoea is:

  • Excessive vaginal discharge associated with pruritus and inflammation
  • Acute unilateral pain and swelling over labia due to the involvement of Bartholin’s gland
  • Intermenstrual bleeding

Non-gynaecological presentation of gonorrhoea is:

  • Pharyngeal infection
  • Dysuria 
  • Rectal discomfort due to associated proctitis.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis is Chlamydia trachomatis.

The causes of non-gonococcal urethritis are:

  1. Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
  2. Ureaplasma urealyticum
  3. Adenovirus 
  4. Haemophillus vaginalis
  5. Mycoplasma genitalium
  6. Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
  7. Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.text: A 35-year-old sex worker was suspected to have chlamydial cervicitis. What is the most sensitive method for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution: The most sensitive method for confirming the diagnosis of chlamydial cervicitis is the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It is fast, highly sensi­tive and specific (96%).

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman had complaints of lower abdominal pain and vaginal discharge. On microscopy, the following finding was present. What is the selective culture media used to isolate the causative organism?

choices.text: Culture on bilayer human blood agar

questions.solution:
Chlamydia trachomatis is the most likely causative organism. This is suggested by the presence of characteristic iodine-stained inclusion bodies in the McCoy cell culture of the patient's endocervical sample.

Chlamydia is a gram-negative coccobacillus. The gram stain of the cervical smear would show abundant leucocytes but no organisms. 

The nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is currently done for the diagnosis of lymphogranuloma venereum.

questions.text: A patient with complaints of vaginal discharge was evaluated. On an endocervical biopsy, chlamydia was detected. How will you treat this patient?
questions.solution:
A single dose of 1 g of azithromycin is given and contact tracing is done to treat a patient diagnosed with a chlamydial infection.

Treatment of chlamydial infection:

  • Azithromycin 1 g single dose (or)
  • Doxycycline 100 mg orally BID × 7 days (or)
  • Ofloxacin 200 mg orally BID × 7 days (or)
  • Erythromycin 500 mg orally BID × 7 days

Contact tracing should always be done. The sexual partner should also be treated with the same regimen.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady complains of thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning. What is the route of administration of the first non-azole drug approved to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning are suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis. The first and the only non-azole antifungal approved for the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis is Ibrexafungerp. The route of administration of this drug is oral.

Ibrexafungerp is a triterpenoid antifungal agent that acts by inhibiting glucan synthase. Glucan synthase is an enzyme involved in the formation of 1,3-beta-D-glucan which is an essential component of the fungal cell wall.

The recommended dosage is 600 mg orally as 2 divided doses 12 hrs apart. Contraindications include pregnancy and hypersensitivity to ibrexafungerp. The most frequent adverse reactions are diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain, dizziness, and vomiting.
